A laser cut mechanical toy based off a planetary gear system.

Cut from 1/8th MDF or plywood. Red lines are etched artwork and black lines are cuts. Vitamins:
4 x M3x12 bolts, 4 x M3 nuts and thread locking compound OR 4x pn 96082A100 tubular press fit rivets from McMaster-Carr. Cut out the parts. Run the 4 bolts up from the bottom. Place the big gears around the outside. Place the gear ring inside the big gears. Put the sun gear on the central post. place the 4 planet gears around the sun. Put the top frame on. If you used bolts, put some lock compound on the nut and screw them down until they a just flush with the top of the bolt. Don't overtighten. If you used press fit rivets, use a vice (or arbor press) to push the tops into the bottoms. Don't overpress. If you are careful you can seat these rivets with a hammer, but a vice works better.

Cufflink designed for wearing with a tuxedo shirt. Suitable for formal occasions or just classing up the workshop.

There are 2 versions of these. 
The ones in the picture with the bowtie are from the file android-cufflink-3.stl and were printed on a printer that has soluble support material. Unfortunately, this version doesn't come out too well without the support material because of a lack of a flat surface area for the base.
I've also uploaded android-cufflink-nobowtie.stl which should print well with the Android oriented face-down. It has a slope to the holder flange on the back of the cuffling to minimize overhang as well.
For finishing I spray-painted with Krylon Chrome paint to give the silver appearance. The bowtie was painted with black acrylic paint after the silver paint had a chance to set.

description.text: Strange Bunny

Here's a little 40mm fan mount I came up with for my Printrbot Simple 2014 with aluminum extruder.  Air is blown directly onto the direct drive gear.  The bracket itself bolts to the top of the Y-carriage using two existing M3x20 bolts.  I also added a filament guide which is compression-fit into the main bracket.  You may need to sand the filament guide down a bit to get it to fit.  I attached my fan to the mount using two extra M3x20 screws & nuts from assembling my Printrbot.  
I'm powering the fan with the 12V power from the heat bed (which I'm not using) and the ground of the 5V E-stop connection.  See photos for details.  Extruder runs cool to the touch during printing.

comments.text:
Another wiring option (If you're not using a heated bed) that allows software control of the fan:
Attach a 100K fixed resistor to the T-BED jumper (to simulate a thermistor) and attach your fan to the heated bed connector on the printrboard.
Use:
M140 S60
to turn on the fan and:
M140 S0
to turn it off.

comments.text: By hooking the fan up using the 12v from the unused heated bed connection and ground from the E-stop does the fan stay on all the time as long as the printer has power or only during a print? Do you have to fake the software into thinking you have a heated bed? Will it power the fan without a thermistor installed? Thanks!
comments.author: AmazingSpanoMan

comments.text:
Fan stays on all the time as long as the printer is plugged in. I did not have to do anything to fool the software into thinking there's a heated bed, it just powered up as soon as I plugged it in. No thermistor needed.
FYI, my Printrboard is Rev D so if yours is different then you may have different results.

Antenna mast half.stl is for mounting a 3/4" pvc pipe to a 1 1/4" antenna mast, for mounting homemade antennas for example.  
Antenna mast to mast half.stl is a coupler for mounting 2x, 1 1/4" antenna masts to each other.  
Both files have holes for #8 bolts to secure them together.  2 prints are needed to make a complete coupler.

You'll need to print a minimum of 2 and most likely 4.  I'd suggest using washers under both the head and nut of the bolt to help distribute the clamping pressure as tightening it down can cause it to delaminate.

description.text:
I had the same problem that everyone else has had, the wires on the x-axis fatigued and broke inside the insulation. I looked at all of the posted solutions and found each of them wanting. The cable chains seemed too heavy, and some of the other solutions didn't control the motion of the cable or required one to reroute the cables. This solution maintains the original cable routing and controls the entire length of the cable. 4/4/16 I have added a new version with a slightly thicker cable carrier to address a potential slicer issue https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pk8g16gRuMc
http://youtu.be/cD0QYTWYgY0

.2mm layer height - 15% infill - 2 shells  
Cut the cable clips open on the top side, as it sits on the build platform.  Be careful, the clips are a bit fragile.  If you break one, just use a little tape to keep the wire attached to the flexible strip.  
The rectangular block attaches to the inside top of the printer.  Slide it back until is touches the rear nut and it will be located in the proper place.  (I like to put some easy-to-remove tape in there first so that I won't have residue from the double stick tape if I have to remove it later.)  In the picture, the rear of the machine is to the right.  You can see the spacer block just touching the nut.  
The cable relief strip is sized so that it accommodates the new cable extensions that MB is sending out to address this problem.  In the picture the rear of the machine is to the right.  You can see the neon yellow cable tie going through the stock MB cable tie anchor.  The connectors do not experience any movement during printing.

description.text:
Turn the socket head screws holding on side panels into thumbscrews.  
I had to take the side panel off so many times to try the different iterations of the x-axis cable strain relief that I finally saw the wisdom of making these screws tool-less.  
JimFouch has a nice design up (thing:219135) but I wanted to design my own with a shape that could only be 3D printed.  They are nicely grippy when you twist them.

.1mm layer height - 3 shells - 15% infill  
You will need to scrape away the sharp bottom edge on the inside of the hole.  Make a little bevel to help ease the bolt head into hole.   
Push it on really hard.  
Done.  
I only did the side panels, because the front and rear panels need other tools to remove.  But sometimes it is really nice to be able to just pop of the side panels, and these thumbscrews make it easy.

description.text: This is a functional model of the pendulum clock said to have been designed by Galileo.  This is designed to be used as a historical teaching model for hands-on student interaction but I make no claims of its historical accuracy.  I simply made it based on his drawings. Students learn about gears and gearing, stored energy (through the rubber band), the escapement mechanism, and the properties of the pendulum.  The pendulum in this clock is designed to enable students to explore how weight and length impact period by making it easy for students to move washers or large nuts along notches on the pendulum (full length and half-way up).

More detailed assembly instructions will be posted shortly. This is designed to be cut from 1/4" (5mm) plywood (I've found that Home Depot's new Purebond plywood works great). It is designed to work with 1/4" dowels but be warned the holes for the gears are very snug (on purpose). The frame is designed to use nylon washers to reduce friction with a 1/4" ID and a 3/8" OD.
I've included new pictures to help with the assembly. Look at the washer spacing for the pendulum and escapement mechanism. Also note that the escapement requires a piece to be glued to it above to enable it to work. It is the small rectangle in the plans.
Finally, I recommend playing a little with the exact placement of the two catches on the pendulum. This model is designed to fit very snugly around the 1/4" dowel and I would adjust it manually until I got it to work correctly and then I'd use a spot of super glue to hold it in place once it is working.

description.text:
Made this to use as a spacer in a 608ZZ Bearing for a M4 Screw on my X Axis Idler. The inner hole may need to be drilled out slightly.
And this is meant to be pressed fit into the bearing. Using it on my I3XL right now and working well.

Going over 100RPM on the bfb extruder ain't 100% reliable so for fast printing a bowden cable is recommended. Note that printing with bowden cable is not as near as precise as with direct drive.
Anyhow, here's the holder for the bowden cable (the M6 nut trap like all the others) made to fit on the part 10056 of the bfb extruder.

• print 2 pcs
  • remove the extruder from rapman
  • remove hot end and part 10056 (the part that holds the set screw)
  • slide the M6 nut holding bowden cable and tighten the hot end, 10056 and cable holder together with M5 screws
  • attach other end of the cable to your extruder using another 2 M5 screws
    • print :)

    some warning messages with some slicers, but this will
    (should) not affect the print.

WHAT TO DO:

  • Insert your phone.
  • Clamp it with a cable strap.
  • Attach a cord (or whatever)

OPTIONAL:
  • Cut the cord for (non-free) iPhone 5 upgrade.

  • 1 cord (or whatever)

My children are in charge of the dishwasher, so they created this to train us adults.  
It has three sides: L=Loading, U=Unloading, W=Washing  
It sits on the counter just above the washing machine and gets flipped forward to the next side each time the cycle moves to the next stage.  
Printed in ABS and solvent smoothed.  The letters are colored in with a sharpie.

.2mm print height - 2 shells - 10% infill.  
Rotate 30 degrees to make base horizontal, or you can rotate it 90 degrees the other way.  It doesn't matter which side is the base, and everything is designed observing the 45 degree overhang constraint.  
ABS, solvent smoothed, colored with a sharpie.

description.text:
Scale model idea for cement casting.
We aren't going to be printing plastic houses any time soon.
Plastic molds or facades are probably feasible for large format 3D printer owners (builders).
3D printed molds are still expensive using commercial filament.
I'd guess a bit over $100 sqr/mtr for a 3mm mold wall thickness.
Home filament extrudes should drop that by a factor of 5 or more.
While we are dreaming - here is a set of mold parts you can play with. This is a quick as dirty test. A real project might incorporate some 3D art scans from thingyverse or some 3D objects derived from your stereo photos.

The plaster set much faster than I expected.
I ran a small test first which took quite a while (30mins) to set.
The piece above was poured in four lots.
The first batch was fairly small and intended to seal the gaps at the bottom. Very little leaked out.
After that I couldn't keep up and the plaster was setting before I was ready.
The piece was large enough that the plaster ended up getting quite warm and hardened quickly.
Bird -1-

title: Monstamaka new connection system
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This a new version of the connection system for the Monstamaka sets. I've printed it with ABS on a replicator 2X. It works pretty well, doesn't need support but a raft is necessary, and can be printed upright or upside down (special thanks to dssguy1 for his comments and ideas that made me reconsider the connection system).
If I have good feedback on this from other 3D printers and material, I will replace the current system on all Monstamaka models (I decided to design a all new system not compatible with the current one rather than making something not so good but compatible).
If you test it, please give feedback. Thanks a lot !

comments.text: Oh, I also wanted to let you know that if you print the parts like the left piece is shown in the picture, the bottom of the part is so thin that most slicers will reject the first couple layers.  Meaning that it will take 2-3 layers before your slicer decides there is enough material needed in the model to lay down any plastic.  Depending on your nozzle size and width of extrusion it may print on layer 2.  I sank my part into the plate .6mm and it printed fine but you might want to just make it a less sharp point on the bottom (at least .4-.6mm wide so slicers will print the first layer).
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text:
Last suggestion for the night. You may also want to move the relief for the connection up a little so you can't see it when the two halves are connected. Right now you can just barely see the V portion of the cut-out, probably moving it .5mm-1mm up will make it inviisible when assembled.
Super excited about how much nicer these parts fit together. I will upload a pic when my 1.75 scale is done.
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text:
Thanks so much for your relevant comments !
I will make the modifications.
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text:
Printed at 1:1 scale and they were a little tight but only required a TINY amount of sanding on the male portion and they fit together perfect. It is nice that you can adjust the tightness of fit with only very minor (10 seconds of 180 grit sand paper) amount of sanding. That way if you have older kids who have much stronger fingers, you can leave them as stock. If you are making for an 18 month old, you can sand them lightly to suit their strength needs without making them so loose that they fall out on their own.
I am printing them at 1.75:1 scale now and will report back if the fit is the same.
comments.author: dssguy1

author: d3nnis

description.text:
This is a unique spinning top I designed in Sketchup. It is designed to be printed in two pieces and glued together also to have an open space in the middle to test the spanning ability of the MakerBot Replicator. both top and bottom are printed at the same time then assembled with 4 drops of superglue at the "corners". I can also post separate .stl files for those of you who want to print it in two colors. See it spin!
http://youtu.be/m3AUyN1N6Ls New version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31671

• Print spinning top.stl (do not use raft or support)
  • Assemble with one small drop of super glue on the flat part of each "corner"
  • Align carefully and squeeze each of the four flat spots together
  • Wait for glue to cure and Spinn!
    • Notes
  • Do not use a raft, the parts on the build platform need to be flat and smooth so they can be glued together.
  • Be careful when removing from build surface. It is super strong when the structure is complete but It can be a bit weak before the top and bottom are joined together.
  • It will print with default replicator setting, but it will print better if you change the following settings:
    • Object infill of 50%
    Layer Hight of .2
    (see screen capture of Gcode window)

title: The Hammers from Pink Floyd's "The Wall"

description.text: I modeled the walking hammers from the 1982 Pink Floyd movie "The Wall". I Cut the model in several parts for printability. I cut the handle parts in a way that can be printed in the red and black colors if you happen to have the materials for it. I used transparent PLA and painted them with airplane model's paint. I also used some glue to be sure the part is solid enough. This is my first design with parts that are assembled together and i had some trouble with the tolerances of my printer. Be sure to read the instructions where I explain how to scale this correctly and some other stuff. As of yet, it doesn't stand by itself, i had to put in some paper wedges. I will try to design some "shoes" so that it stands nicely. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/aPhYIgBKEs4

I designed the hammers way to small so you have to scale it on your slicer software. I used 175%. All of the parts should be scaled EXCEPT THE PF_HAMMER_UNITE. This one is alread made to match the 175% scale, if you use a different size, you should use a different piece to join them. It should not be hard to design one on tinkercad. The tolerances on my Prussa i3 are not so good, and I believe this changes with different layer heights. I used a layer height of about 0.3mm and with the current design i still had to sand some parts to make it all fit nicely. Let me know if you have trouble printing and or if you have some modifications and recommendations. I was able to assemble the parts together after some sanding, so maybe you should be ready to do some post-processing too. print

I saved he model together on the one I posted online. Simple cut 2mm off the bottom and print then simply reprint the 2mm and glue. Or print it upside down.

A different approach for a pan/tilt movement. The "Z-mover" additionally can move the thing inside
back and forth, which might be
useful for a pen. Can also be used to move paddles for a rowing boat model ;-) Video: http://youtu.be/UlFfeajCWjs

Software from the YouTube video is availabe from here:
http://www.askrprojects.net/additional/xyzarm.zip It additionally requires:
  • an Arduino or Chipkit-Max32 (or any compatible)
  • Processing (PC-control): http://processing.org/
  • G4P library for Processing: http://www.lagers.org.uk/g4p/index.html
    • Notice that the fixture is only provided as an example and
    was constructed to hold an 11mm tube.
    You'll need to create your own, custom fixtures... --
    WHAT TO DO:
  • Print the XYArm part.
  • Mount the 2 servos with small metal screws.
  • Create your own fixture:
    ÃÂ ÃÂ  0ÃÂ° (servo, top)
    ÃÂ ÃÂ  90ÃÂ° (servo, right)
    ÃÂ ÃÂ  225ÃÂ° (rubber band, lower left)
  • Attach the fixture to the servos with sewing cotton.
    ÃÂ ÃÂ Fix sewing cotton with super glue (knot or loop).

BOM:
  • 1 x printed part, XYArm (optional: Z-mover)
  • 1 x missing fixture (created by you)
  • 2 x 8mm servo (Robbe FS31, Ripmax SD100, Dymond D47)
  • 4 x small metal screw (appr. 2x5mm)
  • 2 x rubber band
  • 2 x 10cm sewing cotton (alt. aramid- or carbon fiber)

  • 4 x drop of superglue

  • 2 x 5mm screw for mounting
  • 1 x 5mm screw for Z-arm

description.text:
I created a bracket to hold my DeWalt DW660 spindle on my ShapeOko 2.  This bracket conforms pretty well to the non-round shape of the DW660.  I wanted the bracket to be pretty stiff and strong, so I designed it to be hollow and then filled with liquid epoxy.  I use West System's Epoxy.  The walls are all about 1.5mm thick and there is some internal structure.  
The top bracket has a mounting plate for a limit switch.  I used McMaster 7779K22

I printed on Replicator 2 with ReplicatorG software. Settings were:
  • Infill 100% (this fills the 1.5mm walls 100%, not the whole model
  • Shells 0 (if you make >0 there is a bug in skeinforge where it will not fill in the 1.5mm wall all the way)
  • Layer height: 0.2mm
    • I created the STL files by using the Export STL plug-in for SketchUp. Then I ran them through Netfabb's STL fixer. The SketchUp file has a Mouse Ears layer which I like to use to help hold the part flat to the build plate. After the brackets are printed, fill them with liquid epoxy. I used West System's epoxy. It's about as thick a maple syrup, and I just poured it inside. I noticed that the model leaked a little on the face where the two brackets mate. To prevent this I just added a little epoxy at first and let that dry so it would seal that face, then filled it up bracket. The brackets are held together by M5 x 90 bolts. The hex nut for the bolt slips inside a hex shaped counterbore and is held in place with the hex nut retainers. The brackets are bolted to the ShapeOko with M5 x 25 socket head cap screws. I do use washers under the head side; the washers are a tight fit in the counterbore, but they do fit.

description.text:
A base to mount a Raspberry Pi microcontroller on, to reduce the chance of contact of the board with liquids, dust, or metal, and so that the board can be handled more easily.
Allows mounting on clamshell laptop using ClamShelf.
Design based on Model B revision 2 (2012). This stand has beveled sides that slide into the ClamShelf; vents in the beveled sides to allow circulation under the circuit board horizontally, as well as vertically through the open top and bottom; guides to help position the circuit board; and screw holes in the corners so that several stands can be stacked using #4-40 screws, spacers, and nuts.

Download STL file and 3D print. Result should be 3 by 4 by 3/8 inch (76.2 by 101.6 by 9.525mm).
Attach Raspberry Pi using 2 #4-40 by 1/2 inch flat head or oval head machine screws and nuts.
This is a printable interlocking beer mat. With 6 of them, interlocking, you should have a large mat for a vase or dish.

description.text: This is a holder to attach two 8mm smooth rods together for optical experiments. This component is part of the Open-source optics project, whose goal is to radically reduce the cost of scientific optical hardware: by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

Use the OpenSCAD files to customize it for your application, print on your favorite open source 3-D printer and enjoy. This holds two 8mm smooth rods a distance apart for making it easy to have offset optical components from an optical rail. These are held in place with two m3 thumbscrews using the nut traps. Use thumb screw from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30500 to attach it to an 8mm smooth rod. For info on the OpenBeam optical rail see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31370 This component is part of the Open-source Optics Library: Zhang C, Anzalone NC, Faria RP, Pearce JM (2013) Open-Source 3D-Printable Optics Equipment. PLoS ONE 8(3): e59840. This is part of a larger project to reduce the cost of scientific equipment using open-source hardware. Read more here

title: Rostock boxed idler end for 12 tooth T5 pulley

description.text:
Designed to align with the 12 tooth T5 pulley which is going on my CheapStock.
Boxed the bearing shaft so there's less tendency to torque the bearing shaft upon tensioning the belt. Also added additional mounting holes with the intent of sharing some stress with the top panel.
So far, has worked swimmingly - no belt movement, no belt rubbing; nice, low friction even with belts tightened like guitar strings.

Put the 3mm screws and nuts in before mounting the bearing. Assembly is facilitated by plasti-forming the shaft threads:
Thread the rod/bolt into the hole just about half way.
Place an 8mm washer on the rod/bolt in the interior of the box.
Place the first bearing on the rod/bolt.
Thread a little further into the box so rod/bolt extends just past the first bearing.
Place the second bearing on the rod/bolt.
Thread more until flush with second bearing.
Put another washer on.
Thread rod/bolt through.
Tighten it up.

description.text: Basic Arduino bumper with mounting holes.  I used (4) M3x0.5 x 6 screws to attach the Arduino to the bumper.

Provides a clean way to attach your favorite tensioning device to open ended timing belts.
STL fits 6mm wide belts.

Push belt through slot with teeth facing inward.
Wrap around the end.
Eyeball amount of tail to pull back through the terminator.
Place tail into opening.
Put a small screw driver through hole to use as a handle - it can take a bit of force to pull the tail through.
Pull the tail through. May need to push a bit to get teeth to engage. If belt doesn't want to grab the tail, use a razor knife to clean slot opening where tail is being insrted - try to chamfer it a bit more and smooth it out.

Converted inward facing mounts into forward facing ones. Holes should be standard, but are designed for 2001 Kia Optima.
I have yet to get this printed, so I have no idea if actually works.

title: Cosmo-Knob
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Bring the stars inside with our homage to the cosmos!
Follow these simple steps to fill the room with the night's sky:
  • print adapter and knob
  • place adapter on iPhone
  • attach knob to adapter
  • turn on flashlight app
  • turn off the lights and enjoy!
    • The model features northern hemisphere constellations - see if you can follow along with the map! - http://bit.ly/SeKMYM Files:
  • iPhone 4s adapter
  • iPhone 5 adapter
  • Knob01 - 1/16" thick walls
  • Knob02 - 1/32" thick walls
  • Universal adapter
    • We hope you enjoy!
    Simplus Design
    http://simplusdesign.com
    http://fb.com/SimplusDesign
    http://twitter.com/SimplusDesign
    http://instagram.com/SimplusDesign

Raft recommended for knob because of small surface area.  
No support recommended.  
The files are in INCHES. To convert to mm, scale model by 25.4 or use the "Inches -> mm" button in MakerWare.

title: Liquid Cooled Flashforge!  Extruder + XYZ Nema Motors.

description.text:
THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS!
Please "Watch" to follow progress updates for additional photos, files and instructions. I noticed my Nema 17 motors get hot.
I have a CNC Machine.
I have scrap aluminum etc.
I am crazy.
Sooo I decided to make liquid cooling blocks.
Print tank parts,
Print a few water pumps,
etc. Yes I did "Free hand" the milling of the aluminum. That way nobody can say they are commercially bought. Plus I broke two 1/8th milling bits on my first tool path before going 1/4th" so whatever. No big deal. I made 4 cooling blocks for 5 Nema 17s. One block is double wide for the extruders. I will print hose fittings, tank corners, water pumps, and water block to Nema fittings.
Stay tuned. Update May 4th 2014: Added pump files, and dual print version of pump. Nozzle next.

The parts included are for the edges of a water tank for the cooling system.
They have a 2.5mm gap.
When printing the "corner" it is critical that if you have a dual extruder, you print with the lower leg pointing in the direction of the extruder you are NOT using. (i.e.: If you print with your left extruder, then have the lower leg point to the right.) That way the unused extruder will not bump and knock over the part while printing the top 2 legs. I added 4 supports and turned it 45 degrees.
Print with 10% infill
150mm/s extrude
200mm/s travel
NO support
Yes Raft
230F for ABS Use lots of silicone and 2.4mm thick plexiglass or something. Pictures soon! If you attempt to make your own water blocks, I used 6/32 screws, 3/8ths long. Still filed them down. And silicone seal before the plexyglass.
I also used a 1/4th milling bit on a milling machine.
Tapped all holes, even water input/output.
Then filed down the backside with a dermal.

This is a poseable modular, magnetic robot toy.  Make it, share it, sell it, trade it, upgrade it.

I'm working on an instructable to show how the toy is assembled, which can be found here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Davincibots-Create-a-3d-printed-modular-robot-toy/ And here's the short version: Download and print the .stl files. Cut 2 2cm lengths of 4mm diameter dowels. Hot glue them into the shoulder and wrist joints. Hot glue #4 (I think that was the size) countersunk finishing washers into the large cylindrical recesses on the pieces. Hot glue 5mm diameter spherical magnets into the hemispherical recesses. Align the poles properly by holding the magnet in one of the finishing washers as you glue the magnets in place. Assemble all of the pieces to make a Davincibot! I have also attached the .scad file so that you can make changes. It should be mostly parametric. Also, the smile on the robot's head is generated randomly, so each time you render it, you will create a unique robot head.

description.text:
A tool to make lines parallel to the edge of a piece of material.

• Print the parts (I used PLA light infills)

  • Press short #6 bolt into thumbwheel and into slider

description.text: Use this thing to mount a Printruder II on a Mendel's X carriage.

comments.text: Can this mount a Makerbot extruder?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The MK4 plastruder does not work with these; has a problem mating onto the mendel extruder carriage. The MK4 part labelled Insulator Retainer (which mounts your hotend) is in the way. Also the bolts connecting the washer (that supports the hotend) to the Insulator Retainer have their width dimension in the narrow dimension of the carriage hole, they must be rotated 90 degrees about Z axis to fit. In short, need another way to connect the hotend to the extruder; the MK4 plastruder (with no hotend attached) will mount perfectly onto the mendel carriage with these instead of using dinos.

title: Printrbot Simple XL Tower V2 Cable Management Mount

description.text: This is a modification of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:237133 mount that will work with the XL tower. Can use original zip ties to mount or added screw holes and screw directly into tower Some area are a little thin but it still worked for me. I will beef these areas up when i get a chance

Can mount using zip ties or M3 screws. some of the screw holes are a little thin, be careful when threading screws. I only used the top left screw hole and the zip tie that goes through the corner of the Printer board. Also you will want to the new TrackMountYBottom90.stl" and "CableChainOpenBack90.stl" (one of each) at the extruder end so the chain can bend over on its self when it runs into tower. See original design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:237133 I plan to cut a notch in the top of my tower for the chain to pass through because this mod will have you lose an inch off the z-axis when the Y-axis is all the way retracted.
